(CP) - Workers in an industrial park and residents of more than 100 nearby homes scrambled to get out of La Ronge's north side Thursday afternoon after two forest fires threatened their homes and businesses.</p><p nitf:lede="true">By 1 p.m., the RCMP were running from door to door asking people to leave.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- "People were crying,'' said one resident, who loaded up his photo albums and hooked his prized boat to his car before leaving his home with his wife.</p><p>"At that point the fire was about a quarter-mile away.''</p><p>The couple will sleep in the office of the motel they own.</p><p>"There is a conference in town and every motel and hotel room is booked - so we've got no place else to stay,'' said the man, who didn't want to give his name.</p><p>The fire shot six metres above the trees as it roared through the industrial area of town.</p><p>There were conflicting reports over how many businesses were damaged by the blaze. The area the fire skirted housed a wild rice plant, a Shell yard and other industrial shops.</p><p>"I watched the fire, when it was just feet away from an industrial shop, burn the end of the building,'' said the motel owner.</p><p>"The fire moved very, very rapidly,'' said Marty Ballentyne, general manager of radio station CJLR, who said the evacuation went smoothly.</p><p>"The community has pulled together and there is no indication anyone is in danger.''</p><p>Evacuees were being housed in the local health clinic and a hockey arena.</p><p>RCMP decided to order the evacuation when the fire grew dangerously close to a bulk fuel station, said Maureen Vancoughnett, a civilian RCMP staff member.</p><p>Angela Krienke, who works at Eddie's Place restaurant, said the blaze began as a bush fire and grew from there.</p><p>She said a couple of trailers and houses had been badly damaged.</p><p>"A lot of them have bad smoke damage,'' she said. "I heard one house is gone for sure.''</p><p>As well, a couple of new homes were being built in the area. "Those people will have to start over,'' Krienke said.</p><p>Ballentyne said the air was hazy and the smell of smoke was strong, but Krienke said by early evening the smoke had started to thin out.</p><p>Jeanette Krayetski with Environment and Resource Management Saskatchewan said recent high winds and warm temperatures had dried the forest to the point where the fire hazard was extreme.</p><p>Water bombers, helicopters and ground crews were fighting the blazes. Winds on Thursday night were strong, but blowing from the south and pushing the flames away from the town.</p><p>The remote town of 2,800 located on the shores of Lac La Ronge is about 300 kilometres north of Saskatoon.</p><p>It sits on the edge of La Ronge Provincial Park, a popular park for camping, canoeing and fishing.</p><p>In northern Alberta, meanwhile, a forest fire just north of Fort McMurray threatened the region's power supply as it burned out of control Thursday.</p><p>"The forest fires in the Fort McMurray area are threatening two of our large transmission lines that feed the area,'' said Elaine Sagan of Atco Electric.</p><p>"However, at this time both are still in service.''</p><p>There were a number of fires burning near Fort McMurray Thursday, three out of control. None were threatening the town.</p><p>However, forestry officials were mulling over whether to evacuate Janvier, a small aboriginal community about 120 kilometres southeast of Fort McMurray.</p><p>A section of Highway 881, which connects Janvier to the hamlet of Conklin, closed at 2 p.m. due to zero visibility on the road caused by smoke.</p><p>"There was supposed to be a wind change this afternoon and it's a matter of waiting to see if that has come through,'' fire information officer Luc Nowicki said.</p><p>"We haven't advised Disaster Services to evacuate yet. We haven't advised the Janvier band to evacuate yet.'' (CP-Fort McMurray Today)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5GJ0-MDN1-F197-53D9-00000-00What would happen if a windmill caught fire in our woodland forests?2015-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:08:09ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 1What would happen if a windmill caught fire in our woodland forests?

Column - You know something we don't seem to have heard much about in the great debates over windmills farms in our area - windmill fires.

Now, of course the good folks advocating the installation of windmill farms aren't going to bring it up. They have enough concerns from potential neighbours that they don't want another thing muddying the waters.

But a story in the London Daily Mail recently suggests that there are about 120 windmill fires every year. The industry claims that there are only about 12. The figures were compiled by engineers at Imperial College London and Edinburgh University.

"The researchers claim that out of 200,000 turbines world-wide, 117 fires take place annually," the newspaper reported.

OK, so there are always two sides to every story but even if the number is somewhere in the middle, it still seems like a significant risk.

Now, granted that there are windmills all over Europe and the number that catch fire is small compared to the total number of windmills.

But Eastern Ontario is not Europe (not that the Europeans have such a great track record on taking care of the environment anyways).

For one thing, there aren't the great forests in Europe like there are here. And think about it. If a windmill catches fire on a beach in Holland, what is there around it to burn?

But if a windmill in the bush 40 klicks from the Plevna fire station catches fire . . . we're talking raging inferno before anybody can even get to it to start spraying water.

Add to this the wind factor, as in fanning the flames.

Can anybody reasonably argue the winds wouldn't whip up a forest fire when the reason they put these things where they do is because there's already plenty of wind there?

The thing is that wind turbines have a lot of highly flammable materials such as hydraulic oil and plastics in close proximity to machinery and electrical wires. If the machinery is faulty or overheats . . .

Granted the industry takes great pains to prevent fires in their turbines. The beasts cost a lot to put up in the first place and once they're up and running, they generate a ton of revenue that industry officials would be reluctant to part with.

But the best laid plans of mice and men . . .

And the thing is, it would only take one forest fire to make a mess of things in Northern Frontenac County, or Lanark, or L & A.

Because unlike wind farms on European beaches, with all the fuel at hand in an Ontario forest, how long would it take for one blown burning turbine to ignite another, and another and another?

We all want to save the planet and be good to the environment and, yes, wind power seems like a good alternative source of energy.

But it also sounds like wind farms in forests could be a disaster just waiting to happen.

Officials said they found the charred body of a 40-year-old man in the area.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AP</p></bodyText></section><p>The deputy fire chief, Andreas Kois, said the fires were "under complete control,'' but crews would remain in the area until Thursday because of fears the strong winds could rekindle the flames.</p><p>The cause of the fire was not immediately known, but past summer wildfires in Greece have been blamed on extremely dry brush and land developers seeking to take advantage of laws that allow construction on burned land.</p><p>More than a dozen houses were destroyed by the fire, which was pushed by strong winds toward the suburbs of Acharnes and Thrakomakedones, about 15 kilometres north of central Athens. Greece's ability to battle seasonal wildfires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5SBS-TSJ1-JDH3-G4HT-00000-00Federal researchers forecast long, hot wildfire season2018-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:08:08ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A4Federal researchers forecast long, hot wildfire seasonBob WeberThe Canadian Press

Federal wildfire researchers say most regions in Canada could be facing a long, hot, fiery summer.

Wildfire starts and the amount of land burned were below average for the first few weeks of the season, but dry weather is turning things around, said Richard Carr, a fire research analyst with Natural Resources Canada.

"We've had a long, lingering winter and a bit of a slow start to the fire season, but the numbers are higher than the same time last year."

Across the country, wildfire starts have been above average since the end of April. On the national fire danger map, the risk in almost all of the three most westerly provinces is rated at least high. Saskatchewan shows as almost entirely extreme.

Two provinces have already had their first evacuations of the year. About 40 people in Crutwell, Sask., have had to flee their homes at least twice. Seven families in Lac du Bonnet, Man., also had to leave.

Manitoba has counted 119 fires so far. Last year at this time, the figure was 27 and the year before that it was 58.

Nationally, the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre says Canada is about 100 fires ahead of the 10-year average for early May.

Although some parts of the country are flooding, much of the forested area remains dry, said Carr.

"It's pretty dry across that whole stretch, right from British Columbia to western Ontario."

Ontario has banned open fires in its northwest and Alberta has posted bans in many parks and municipalities. A ban in Saskatchewan covers Crown land in provincial parks, except in the Cypress Hills.

More worrisome are Environment Canada's weather predictions for the summer. Although precipitation is difficult to predict and some rainy relief is expected by July, Carr said the data suggests it will mostly be hot and dry.

"There's still a fair amount of Canada that's showing drier than normal conditions," he said. "If we get rain during that time, we might go into a lull and have a normal summer. But if it stays dry - and it looks like there's a chance that it might - we might be a busier season.

Join watershed champion and storyteller Vanessa Scott for a unique evening of original photography, Dec. 6 at the Lion's Den in Comox. The Comox Valley Paddlers Club's guest will explore the value of headwaters and local rivers that connect forests to the sea.

In August, Scott joined a once-in-a-lifetime paddling voyage through the headwaters of the Fraser River during the Rivershed Society of BC's annual freshwater journey from the foothills of the Rocky Mountains following the route of wild salmon to the Pacific Ocean.

As part of this Sustainable Living and Leadership Program, Scott paddled a 14-person voyageur canoe through the Robson Valley from Tete Juane Cache to McBride, alongside other water champions from across B.C. The unexpected backdrop of the forest fire emergency - plus wild salmon's will to survive in an era of climate change - provided Scott with a front row seat to some of the biggest issues in B.C., and galvanized her passion for water.

"Despite being B.C.'s most endangered river, the Fraser is still the largest, most productive wild salmon river in the world," said Scott, a kayaker who grew up sailing in the Pacific Northwest and the Mediterranean. "But the Comox Valley's headwaters and salmon streams are just as important, unique and worthy of respect in their own ways."

Scott's 45-minute talk with Q&A will also highlight efforts to protect and restore local water assets across the Comox Valley as a way to offer clear insight for positive, collaborative actions.

"As I spoke in communities along the Fraser River this summer, people were inspired by the great work being done right here," she said. "From the Comox Lake drinking watershed to Kus-kus-sum and the Morrison Creek effort to protect the last intact headwaters on the East Coast of Vancouver Island, we are coming together around values of water and salmon for a better future."

Scott collaborates with the CV Land Trust, CV Conservation Partnership, Project Watershed and other groups, and is using her Fraser River adventure story to support local campaigns. She is a director with the Brooklyn Creek Watershed Society in Comox.

Her talk is at 7 p.m. at the Lion's Den, 1729 Comox Ave. Members are free. Guests are $5.

Other events may also be of interest to the community. Early next year, the club has planned an evening with local Marine SAR. This will be of interest to all pleasure boaters as it will discuss safety and emergency rescue issues and processes. There's also an evening with a local ornithologist who will be discussing coastal birds and how to help protect their nesting grounds.

EDS: ADDS dropped word fire' to lede, CORRECTS spelling of Nimchuk in para 5, minor editing throughout; INDEX: Environment, Health, Forestry; HL:Rainy weather helps firefighters corral Alberta's biggest forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>EDMONTON</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>EDMONTON (CP) - Firefighters, aided by a rainy, cool weekend, have finally corralled Alberta's largest forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true">After weeks of raging out of control, a massive fire near Chisholm, about 150 kilometres north of Edmonton, was listed Monday as being held.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- That means the fire has been contained and is unlikely to grow, said Pat Loewen, fire information officer for Alberta Sustainable Resources.</p><p>The blaze has charred 1,160 square kilometres of land, nearly twice the size of Toronto, and destroyed nine homes in the hamlet of Chisholm.</p><p>Government meteorologist Nick Nimchuk said up to 50 millimetres of rain fell on the fire in the last week, including a steady drizzle over the weekend.</p><p>Timber, leaves and branches are now moistened so they're tougher to burn.</p><p>"A bit every day for several days in a row is a very effective way of wetting the fuels instead of getting one large amount all at one time,'' Nimchuk said.</p><p>Loewen said the fire was smouldering and creating a lot of smoke on Monday.</p><p>Firefighters with portable water pumps were dousing hot spots.</p><p>"They'll be digging that particular area up, just like with your campfire,'' Loewen said.</p><p>"What we'd like you to do with your campfires is to make sure you can put your hand in the ashes before you go. Pour water on it, stir it up, and pour water on it again. That's what they will be doing.''</p><p>However, Loewen said the war is far from over with the Chisholm fire.</p><p>"We have a lot of work to do. We're hoping Mother Nature stays on our side. If we jump back immediately into hot, dry windy weather, we stand the risk of having some difficulties with it again,'' he said.</p><p>Residents of nearby Smith and Hondo remained Monday on evacuation alert.</p><p>To date this year, 401 fires in Alberta have destroyed 1,500 square kilometres of land. Battling the fires has cost Alberta taxpayers $36 million.</p><p>The Chisholm fire alone has cost $10 million.</p><p>No fires were listed out of control on Monday.</p><p>There were 514 firefighters working on the Chisholm fire on Monday, along with 34 helicopters, 31 dozers, 35 water trucks and 20 skidders.</p><p>The forecast for the next few days was for cool temperatures, low winds and a chance of showers over the fire area.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
